content: Career Path: Software Engineer at Škoda Auto. Entry-level Software Engineers typically require a Bachelor's degree in Computer Science, Software Engineering, or related field. Key skills include proficiency in programming languages (C++, Python, Java), understanding of automotive software standards (AUTOSAR, ISO 26262), and experience with embedded systems. Junior Engineers work on vehicle control units, infotainment systems, and diagnostic tools. Progression path: Junior Software Engineer (0-2 years) → Software Engineer (2-5 years) → Senior Software Engineer (5+ years) → Technical Lead or Architect. Recommended certifications: AUTOSAR Fundamentals, ISO 26262 Functional Safety.

Career Path: Technical Lead at Škoda Auto. To become a Technical Lead, you need 5+ years of experience in software development, with at least 2 years in automotive software. Required skills include advanced proficiency in C++/Python, deep understanding of AUTOSAR architecture, experience with CAN/LIN/FlexRay protocols, leadership capabilities, and project management skills. Technical Leads oversee development teams, make architectural decisions, and coordinate with cross-functional teams including hardware engineers and quality assurance. Recommended path: Senior Software Engineer → Technical Lead → Engineering Manager or Principal Architect. Essential training: Škoda Auto Leadership Workshop, Advanced AUTOSAR Architecture Course, Agile Project Management Certification.

Career Path: Project Manager at Škoda Auto. Project Managers in automotive software require a blend of technical understanding and management skills. Typical requirements include Bachelor's degree in Engineering or Business, 3+ years of project management experience, PMP or PRINCE2 certification, understanding of automotive development lifecycle (V-model), and proficiency in Agile/Scrum methodologies. Project Managers coordinate software development projects, manage timelines and budgets, communicate with stakeholders, and ensure compliance with automotive standards. Career progression: Junior Project Manager → Project Manager → Senior Project Manager → Program Manager. Key skills: Risk management, stakeholder communication, automotive domain knowledge, and proficiency in project management tools (Jira, Confluence).

Career Path: Test Engineer at Škoda Auto. Test Engineers ensure software quality and compliance with automotive safety standards. Entry requirements include Bachelor's degree in Engineering or Computer Science, knowledge of testing methodologies, understanding of ISO 26262 functional safety, and experience with test automation tools. Test Engineers design test cases, execute manual and automated tests, perform HIL (Hardware-in-the-Loop) testing, and validate software against requirements. Career path: Junior Test Engineer → Test Engineer → Senior Test Engineer → Test Lead or Quality Assurance Manager. Essential skills: Test automation (Python, CAPL), understanding of automotive protocols (CAN, LIN), knowledge of testing frameworks (pytest, Robot Framework), and attention to detail. Recommended training: Škoda Auto Testing Excellence Program, ISO 26262 Testing Certification.

Skills Matrix: Software Engineering Roles at Škoda Auto. Software Engineer: Core skills include C++/Python programming, embedded systems, AUTOSAR basics, version control (Git), and debugging. Senior Software Engineer: Advanced C++, AUTOSAR architecture, design patterns, code review, mentoring, and performance optimization. Technical Lead: All Senior Engineer skills plus team leadership, architecture design, technical decision-making, stakeholder management, and cross-functional collaboration. Project Manager: Project management methodologies (Agile/Scrum), risk management, budget planning, stakeholder communication, automotive domain knowledge, and tools (Jira, Confluence). Test Engineer: Test automation, test case design, HIL testing, ISO 26262 knowledge, Python/CAPL scripting, and quality assurance processes. All roles require understanding of automotive standards, safety requirements, and collaborative teamwork.

Technical Skills for Škoda Auto Software Development. Programming Languages: C++ (essential for embedded systems), Python (for automation and testing), Java (for Android Auto integration), CAPL (for CANoe testing). Automotive Standards: AUTOSAR (Classic and Adaptive), ISO 26262 (Functional Safety), ISO 14229 (UDS diagnostics), MISRA C/C++ coding standards. Communication Protocols: CAN (Controller Area Network), LIN (Local Interconnect Network), FlexRay, Ethernet, SOME/IP. Development Tools: Vector CANoe/CANalyzer, MATLAB/Simulink, Git version control, Jira/Confluence, CI/CD pipelines, Docker. Embedded Systems: Real-time operating systems (RTOS), microcontroller programming, memory management, interrupt handling. Software Architecture: Design patterns, UML modeling, software architecture patterns, component-based development. Cloud Technologies: AWS/Azure basics for connected vehicle services, containerization, microservices architecture.

Soft Skills for Škoda Auto Employees. Leadership: Ability to guide teams, make decisions, and inspire others. Essential for Technical Leads and Senior Engineers. Communication: Clear written and verbal communication, ability to explain technical concepts to non-technical stakeholders, multilingual capabilities (English, Czech, German). Collaboration: Working effectively in cross-functional teams, knowledge sharing, mentoring junior colleagues. Problem-Solving: Analytical thinking, creative solutions, debugging complex issues, root cause analysis. Adaptability: Learning new technologies quickly, adapting to changing requirements, embracing agile methodologies. Time Management: Meeting deadlines, prioritizing tasks, managing multiple projects. Attention to Detail: Critical for safety-critical software, thorough code reviews, comprehensive testing. Cultural Awareness: Understanding of Škoda Auto values, respect for diverse perspectives, international collaboration.

Training Program: AUTOSAR Fundamentals at Škoda Academy. This comprehensive 5-day course covers the AUTOSAR (AUTomotive Open System ARchitecture) standard, essential for automotive software development at Škoda Auto. Topics include AUTOSAR architecture overview, software components (SWCs), communication stacks, BSW (Basic Software) modules, RTE (Runtime Environment), and configuration tools. The course includes hands-on exercises with Vector DaVinci Configurator and practical examples from Škoda vehicle projects. Target audience: Software Engineers, System Architects, and Technical Leads. Prerequisites: Basic knowledge of embedded systems and C programming. Upon completion, participants receive Škoda Academy AUTOSAR Fundamentals Certificate. This training is mandatory for all new software engineers working on AUTOSAR-based projects. Advanced AUTOSAR courses are available for experienced developers.

Training Program: ISO 26262 Functional Safety at Škoda Academy. This critical 4-day training program covers ISO 26262 standard for functional safety in road vehicles. Participants learn about safety lifecycle, hazard analysis and risk assessment (HARA), safety goals, functional safety requirements, technical safety requirements, and verification/validation processes. The course includes case studies from Škoda vehicle projects, practical exercises on safety analysis, and guidance on creating safety documentation. Target audience: Software Engineers, System Engineers, Test Engineers, and Project Managers working on safety-critical systems. Prerequisites: Basic understanding of automotive systems. Certification: Škoda Academy ISO 26262 Functional Safety Certificate. This training is required for engineers working on ASIL (Automotive Safety Integrity Level) classified systems. Advanced courses cover ASIL D development and safety case creation.

Training Program: Škoda Auto Leadership Workshop. This intensive 3-day leadership development program is designed for Technical Leads, Senior Engineers, and emerging leaders. The workshop covers leadership fundamentals, team management, conflict resolution, effective communication, decision-making frameworks, and change management. Participants engage in role-playing exercises, case studies from Škoda projects, and receive personalized feedback. Topics include: Building high-performing teams, managing technical debt, balancing innovation with delivery, stakeholder management, and fostering inclusive work environments. Target audience: Technical Leads, Senior Engineers, Team Leads, and Engineering Managers. Prerequisites: Minimum 3 years of professional experience and recommendation from direct manager. The workshop includes follow-up coaching sessions and access to Škoda Leadership Network. Completion leads to eligibility for advanced leadership programs and management positions.

Training Program: Agile and Scrum for Automotive Software Development at Škoda Academy. This 3-day course adapts Agile methodologies specifically for automotive software development constraints. Topics include Scrum framework, Sprint planning, Daily standups, Sprint reviews and retrospectives, Product backlog management, Agile estimation techniques, and handling regulatory requirements in Agile environments. The course addresses unique challenges in automotive development: long hardware lead times, safety-critical requirements, supplier coordination, and compliance documentation. Participants learn to balance agility with automotive standards (ISO 26262, ASPICE). Target audience: Project Managers, Scrum Masters, Product Owners, and Development Team Members. Prerequisites: Basic understanding of software development lifecycle. Certification: Škoda Academy Agile Practitioner Certificate. Advanced courses available: Certified Scrum Master (CSM) and SAFe (Scaled Agile Framework) for large-scale projects.

Training Program: Testing Excellence Program at Škoda Academy. This comprehensive 4-day program covers advanced testing methodologies for automotive software. Topics include: Test strategy and planning, test case design techniques (equivalence partitioning, boundary value analysis), test automation frameworks (pytest, Robot Framework), HIL (Hardware-in-the-Loop) testing, SIL (Software-in-the-Loop) testing, test data management, and test reporting. The course includes hands-on exercises with CANoe, Python test automation, and real Škoda test scenarios. Participants learn about ISO 26262 testing requirements, ASPICE testing processes, and continuous integration testing. Target audience: Test Engineers, Quality Assurance Engineers, and Software Engineers involved in testing. Prerequisites: Basic programming knowledge and understanding of software testing fundamentals. Certification: Škoda Academy Testing Excellence Certificate. Advanced modules cover performance testing, security testing, and AI-based test generation.

Training Program: Python for Automotive Automation at Škoda Academy. This 3-day hands-on course teaches Python programming specifically for automotive software development and testing. Topics include: Python fundamentals, object-oriented programming, working with CAN/LIN protocols using python-can library, test automation with pytest, data analysis with pandas, API development for vehicle diagnostics, scripting for CI/CD pipelines, and integration with automotive tools (CANoe, Vector tools). The course includes practical projects: creating automated test scripts, building diagnostic tools, and developing data analysis dashboards. Target audience: Software Engineers, Test Engineers, and Automation Engineers. Prerequisites: Basic programming knowledge (any language). Certification: Škoda Academy Python Automation Certificate. This training is highly recommended for engineers working on test automation, data analysis, and tool development. Advanced courses cover machine learning for automotive applications.

Training Program: Connected Vehicles and Cloud Services at Škoda Academy. This 4-day course covers modern connected vehicle technologies and cloud integration. Topics include: Vehicle-to-cloud communication, telematics systems, over-the-air (OTA) updates, cloud architecture (AWS/Azure), RESTful APIs, microservices architecture, data analytics, cybersecurity for connected vehicles, and privacy considerations. Participants learn about Škoda Connect platform, integration patterns, and best practices for scalable cloud services. The course includes hands-on labs with cloud platforms and vehicle simulators. Target audience: Software Engineers, Cloud Architects, and System Engineers working on connected vehicle projects. Prerequisites: Basic understanding of networking and software architecture. Certification: Škoda Academy Connected Vehicles Certificate. This training is essential for engineers working on Škoda Connect, eMobility services, and future autonomous vehicle projects.

Industry Trends: Electrification Skills at Škoda Auto. The automotive industry is rapidly transitioning to electric vehicles, creating new skill requirements. Key emerging skills include: Battery management systems (BMS) development, electric powertrain control, charging infrastructure integration, energy management algorithms, thermal management systems, and high-voltage safety systems. Škoda Auto is investing heavily in eMobility, with the ENYAQ iV and upcoming electric models. Engineers need to understand: Power electronics, electric motor control, battery chemistry basics, charging protocols (CCS, CHAdeMO), and energy efficiency optimization. Recommended training: Škoda Academy eMobility Fundamentals Course, Battery Technology Workshop, and Electric Powertrain Control Systems. Career opportunities: BMS Software Engineer, Charging Infrastructure Engineer, eMobility System Architect. These roles require traditional automotive software skills plus specialized knowledge in electric vehicle systems.

Industry Trends: Autonomous Driving and ADAS Skills. Autonomous driving technology is transforming the automotive industry, requiring new competencies. Key skills include: Computer vision and image processing, sensor fusion (camera, radar, LiDAR), machine learning and deep learning, path planning algorithms, perception systems, and functional safety for autonomous systems (SOTIF - Safety of the Intended Functionality). Škoda Auto is developing advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS) and preparing for higher levels of automation. Engineers need expertise in: Python/C++ for AI development, TensorFlow/PyTorch frameworks, ROS (Robot Operating System), simulation environments, and real-time processing. Recommended training: Škoda Academy ADAS Development Course, Machine Learning for Automotive Applications, and SOTIF Training. Career paths: ADAS Software Engineer, Perception Engineer, Autonomous Systems Architect. These roles combine traditional automotive software development with AI/ML expertise.

Industry Trends: Automotive Cybersecurity Skills. As vehicles become more connected, cybersecurity is critical. Key skills include: Secure coding practices, threat modeling, penetration testing, cryptographic protocols, secure communication (TLS, VPN), intrusion detection systems, and security standards (ISO 21434). Škoda Auto implements comprehensive cybersecurity measures across all connected vehicle systems. Engineers need to understand: Network security, embedded system security, secure boot and firmware updates, key management systems, and security testing methodologies. Recommended training: Škoda Academy Automotive Cybersecurity Course, Secure Coding Workshop, and ISO 21434 Training. Career opportunities: Automotive Security Engineer, Security Architect, Penetration Tester. These roles require traditional software engineering skills plus specialized cybersecurity knowledge. The demand for cybersecurity experts in automotive is growing rapidly as vehicles become software-defined platforms.

Industry Trends: Software-Defined Vehicles (SDV). The automotive industry is shifting toward software-defined vehicles, where software capabilities define vehicle features and value. Key skills include: Service-oriented architecture (SOA), cloud-native development, containerization (Docker, Kubernetes), microservices, API design, over-the-air (OTA) updates, and continuous integration/deployment (CI/CD). Škoda Auto is developing next-generation vehicle architectures based on centralized computing platforms. Engineers need expertise in: Modern software architecture patterns, cloud platforms (AWS, Azure), DevOps practices, API gateway management, and software lifecycle management. Recommended training: Škoda Academy SDV Architecture Course, Cloud Native Development Workshop, and DevOps for Automotive. Career paths: SDV Architect, Cloud Integration Engineer, Software Platform Engineer. These roles bridge traditional automotive engineering with modern software development practices. The future of automotive software development will increasingly resemble cloud software development.

Career Path: System Architect at Škoda Auto. System Architects design overall software architectures for vehicle systems, requiring deep technical expertise and broad system understanding. Requirements include: 8+ years of software development experience, 3+ years in architecture design, expertise in AUTOSAR (Classic and Adaptive), understanding of vehicle electrical architecture, and strong communication skills. System Architects define system requirements, create architecture designs, select technologies, coordinate with hardware teams, and ensure compliance with standards. Career progression: Senior Software Engineer → Technical Lead → System Architect → Principal Architect or Engineering Manager. Essential skills: System design, UML/SysML modeling, requirements engineering, trade-off analysis, and stakeholder management. Recommended training: Škoda Academy System Architecture Course, AUTOSAR Adaptive Architecture, and Requirements Engineering Workshop. System Architects play a crucial role in defining Škoda's future vehicle software platforms.

Skills by Seniority Level at Škoda Auto. Junior Level (0-2 years): Core programming skills, basic AUTOSAR knowledge, version control, following coding standards, learning from senior colleagues, and completing assigned tasks. Mid-Level (2-5 years): Independent development, code reviews, mentoring juniors, understanding system architecture, contributing to design decisions, and taking ownership of features. Senior Level (5-8 years): Technical leadership, architecture contributions, mentoring multiple engineers, driving technical initiatives, cross-functional collaboration, and representing team in technical discussions. Lead/Principal Level (8+ years): Strategic technical decisions, defining technical direction, influencing organization-wide practices, advanced problem-solving, and thought leadership. Each level requires increasing depth in technical skills, broader system understanding, stronger leadership capabilities, and greater business acumen. Škoda Auto provides clear progression frameworks and regular performance reviews to support career growth.

Training Program: Škoda Auto Mentorship Program. The Mentorship Program pairs experienced engineers with junior colleagues to support career development and knowledge transfer. Mentors provide guidance on technical skills, career planning, Škoda Auto culture, and professional development. The program includes structured meetings, goal setting, skill assessments, and regular check-ins. Mentors receive training on effective mentoring techniques, communication skills, and providing constructive feedback. Benefits for mentees: Accelerated learning, career guidance, expanded network, and increased confidence. Benefits for mentors: Leadership development, recognition, knowledge reinforcement, and contribution to team success. The program runs for 12 months with optional extension. Participation is voluntary and open to all engineers. Successful completion is recognized in performance reviews and can contribute to promotion considerations. The program fosters a culture of continuous learning and knowledge sharing at Škoda Auto.

Training Program: Code Review Excellence at Škoda Academy. This 2-day workshop teaches effective code review practices essential for maintaining high software quality at Škoda Auto. Topics include: Code review best practices, identifying common issues (security, performance, maintainability), providing constructive feedback, using code review tools (GitLab, GitHub, Gerrit), reviewing AUTOSAR-compliant code, checking MISRA compliance, and balancing thoroughness with efficiency. The course includes hands-on exercises with real code examples from Škoda projects, role-playing scenarios, and peer review practice. Target audience: All Software Engineers, Technical Leads, and Senior Engineers. Prerequisites: Basic programming experience and familiarity with version control systems. Certification: Škoda Academy Code Review Certificate. Effective code reviews are critical for automotive software quality and safety. This training helps establish consistent review standards across all development teams.

Skills by Department at Škoda Auto. Powertrain Software: Engine control algorithms, transmission control, calibration, MATLAB/Simulink, and hardware-in-the-loop testing. Body Electronics: Door/window control, lighting systems, comfort features, LIN/CAN communication, and low-level driver development. Infotainment: Android Auto/CarPlay integration, HMI development, multimedia systems, and user experience design. Chassis Control: ABS, ESP, suspension control, safety-critical systems, and ISO 26262 compliance. Connected Services: Cloud integration, telematics, OTA updates, API development, and cybersecurity. Test & Validation: Test automation, HIL testing, test strategy, quality assurance, and test tool development. Each department requires specialized domain knowledge while sharing common software engineering fundamentals. Cross-department collaboration is essential for integrated vehicle systems. Škoda Auto encourages engineers to gain experience across multiple departments for broader career development.

Career Path: Quality Assurance Manager at Škoda Auto. QA Managers ensure software quality and compliance with automotive standards across development teams. Requirements include: 5+ years in testing/QA, 2+ years in management, deep understanding of ISO 26262 and ASPICE, experience with quality management systems, and strong leadership skills. QA Managers define quality strategies, establish testing processes, manage QA teams, coordinate with development teams, ensure compliance, and report to senior management. Career progression: Test Engineer → Senior Test Engineer → Test Lead → QA Manager → Senior QA Manager or Quality Director. Essential skills: Quality management, process improvement, team leadership, standards compliance (ISO 26262, ASPICE, ISO 9001), risk management, and metrics analysis. Recommended training: Škoda Academy Quality Management Course, ASPICE Process Improvement, and Leadership Workshop. QA Managers play a critical role in maintaining Škoda Auto's reputation for quality and safety.
